Author: pmjordan
Content:
There's

http://searchyc.com/

Or alternatively your favourite search engine with the site:news.ycombinator.com operator (or equivalent).

This is definitely a frequently asked question but sadly not covered in the FAQ.

In fairness, searchyc.com is the top result on google for any of "search ycombinator", "search y combinator" or "search hacker news", so you didn't look very hard.

Author: subwindow
Content:
The use of deprecated HTML tags and bad practices in general stopped me from exploring Arc further. I found I couldn't hack the HN code without first fixing all of the HTML. Fixing all of the HTML is a herculean task because it's mixed up with all the code, instead of in some kind of template system.

Arc might be a good language for certain things, but it is obvious that PG hadn't made a serious web app in 10 years. Lots of these (framework-agnostic) design decisions have been settled for 5+ years now, and for good reason.

Author: silentbicycle
Content:
The vast majority of said features are in modules that aren't loaded by default. Not all of them, but most.

In other words, they are removed by default.

Author: davidw
Content:
> "The Long Tail" seems to have followed the template of many Wired articles: take a partly true, modestly interesting, tech-friendly idea and puff it up to Second Coming proportions.

That template is true for many business books, which is why sites like my own Squeezed Books, and others exist: it's easy to extract the meaningful bits.

Author: coglethorpe
Content:
I listened to the audiobook of "The Long Tail" and maybe I misunderstood it. I thought it was showing how the internet can lead to better choices for consumers and give an outlet for niche content creators to sell their wares. In my mind it's done both. If it acts as a rising tide, lifting the fortunes of the head as well as the tail, all the better.

There are big winners among sites, like YouTube, but there also are niche winners like TechCrunch which has done very well against big media companies by finding its niche. Not to mention places like Hacker News which I visit far more often then TechCrunch and YouTube combined.

Author: dazzawazza
Content:
For python I can't recommend a book. Dive in to Python is available online but to be honest the best thing to do is just start using it. It's just not hard.

DIP: http://www.diveintopython.org/toc/index.html

Tutorial: http://docs.python.org/tut/tut.html

Std Modules: http://docs.python.org/modindex.html

Std Library Reference: http://docs.python.org/lib/lib.html

good luck

Author: gaius
Content: This is because most of the most important numerical libraries (e.g. LINPACK, EISPACK, LAPACK) are written in FORTRAN. There's (literally) decades of work in these libraries, and everyone uses them, and it's simply not worth trying to rewrite them in whatever the language du jour is.
